description:
Email sent 08/05/25.  Further photos to be sent today 26/05/25 by email or download  Our Weeping Birch (T14-1971), has suddenly died in the front garden (north boundary).  It was one of a pair that was the subject of a TPO.  Please may we have permission to remove it?  We have honey fungus in our garden and it is killing a lot of plants and trees.  
The matching Weeping Birch (T15-1971) which was planted alongside this dead one, was felled in 2010.  We spoke to Bob Roper (Principal Planner) at the time and he gave verbal permission to Keith and Bill (Essex Tree Surgeons) and to us, to remove the tree.   We followed up by sending an email with photos, plus a follow-up letter to him.  I have kept copies of our correspondence and will send copies by email (or download) today 26/05/25 to you.
As the trees were planted symmetrically along the north boundary, we were waiting for the surviving Weeping Birch to die before replacing the pair with two identical trees.  The present tree has looked sick for a very long time.   Do you want us to replace one tree, or both?  The honey fungus is currently in the soil and is moving along the north boundary, killing a great number of plants.  If we were to replant this year, the fungus may well attack the new trees.   We do have a very large Maple, also on the north boundary and there is a huge Sweet Chestnut fairly close to us, that straddles the east boundary with next door (Nos. 1 and 2, Astwood Close, Herbert Road.)  I will make a sketch to help you although you are very welcome to make a home visit to look at the tree and it's proximity to others.
We do not yet have a preference for tree type( if the trees need to be replaced), although they would probably need to be smaller types of tree, as we have extra-large trees close by.
application_type_full: Tree works: Trees in conservation areas/subject to TPOs
decision_conditions: The work for which consent is granted shall be carried out to the standards detailed in British Standard Document BS 3998:2010.
To ensure that the work is carried out in accordance with good arboricultural practice.
The work for which consent is granted shall be carried out within 2 years from the date of this consent.
To prevent the accumulation of consents.

That the tree(s) for which consent for removal is granted shall be replaced by [set out details of replacement tree(s), include size on planting, species and location] within the first available planting season (November to March) following the removal of the original tree(s). Failure to plant the replacement tree(s) as required can lead to enforcement action.
THE APPLICANT SHALL NOTIFY THE LOCAL PLANNING AUTHORITY IN WRITING WITHIN TWO MONTHS OF THE PLANTING BEING CARRIED OUT, SO THAT THE REPLACEMENT TREE CAN BE INSPECTED.
In the interests of public amenity and to enable the Council to update its records.

It is suggested that you engage the services of a qualified and fully insured tree surgeon to carry out the above work on your behalf (you should ask to see the contractor's insurance certificate and make sure that it is up to date).
The applicant is advised that if you wish to carry out further works to the above tree[s] you will need to obtain our further consent.

Anyone who takes, damages or destroys the nest of any wild bird whilst that nest is in use or being built is guilty of an offence under the Wildlife and Countryside Act 1981 and prior to commencing work you should ensure that no nesting birds will be affected.

Anyone who kills, injures or disturbs bats, obstructs access to bat roosts or damages or disturbs bat roosts, even when unoccupied by bats, is guilty of an offence under the Wildlife and Countryside Act 1981, the Countryside and Rights of Way Act 2000 and the Conservation (Natural Habitats, &c.) Regulations 2007. Prior to commencing work you should ensure that no bats or bat roosts would be affected. If it is suspected that a bat or bat roost is likely to be affected by the proposed works, you should consult Natural England (tel. 0845 6003078)

Please note that if the work for which consent is granted is not carried out within 2 years of the date of this letter, it will be necessary to submit a fresh application if it is intended to implement the work.

You should comply with British Standard No. 3998 'Recommendations for Tree Work' a copy of which can be inspected at this office. You are advised that the work should be undertaken by a competent and suitably qualified tree contractor.
